conclusion: Problem involves a charged sphere hanging from a thread in equilibrium due to a uniform electric field.
Sphere is pulled to point B at the same height as point O and released from rest.
Objective is to find the speed at the lowest point C and the tension in the string there.
Forces acting on the sphere at equilibrium at point A include gravity, electric force, and tension.
Gravity acts downward on the sphere.
Electric force acts horizontally to the right.
Tension is exerted by the string along its direction.
At equilibrium, tension balances gravitational and electric forces.
Horizontal component: T sinθ = F_e
Vertical component: T cosθ = mg
Express tension T as T = mg / cosθ.
Electric force F_e = mg tanθ.
Given θ = 30°, tanθ = 1/√3.
Calculate F_e = mg / √3.
Sphere swings like a pendulum from point B to point C.
At point B, sphere is at rest with initial velocity u = 0.
Height of B relative to C is L.
Use conservation of mechanical energy to find velocity v at point C.
Total mechanical energy is not conserved due to work done by electric force.
Use work-energy principle: W_net = ΔK.
Net work is sum of work done by gravity and electric force.
Tension does not do work as it is perpendicular to motion.
Calculate W_gravity = mgh = mgL.
Electric force does work as sphere moves from B to C.
Horizontal displacement from B to C is L.
